bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, June 12, 1929

div1.p: Carter expresses how heartbreaking the delays on the editing of the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever have been, but is hopeful the work will be completed by the end of the summer.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, June 12, 1929
div1.opener:
Book,
Misel, Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
June 12, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Your good letter of June 10th. has just reached me and is
much appreciated.

I am glad you approved my tentative plan of going to the
Virginia mountains prior to working with Dr. Frost in August. I doubt
whether I can get off before the latter part of this month, however, as
Dr. Frost wants me to spend a couple of days in Baltimore prior to his
sailing, but, from present indications, not until he has finished up
his other work.

With yourself, I do most earnestly hope that the work can be
completed this summer. The delays have been heartbreaking, even with
all the kindness and understanding shown by yourself and Dr. Vincent--
the more distressing in that they were so totally unexpected--my severe
illness of the fall and winter before last and that wretchéd flu epidemic
of last fall and winter which so completely disrupted Dr. Frost's
plans for our working to-gether --i. e. with me to “interpret” involved
bibliographic cards while he did the final editing. Well, the cards
are nol longer involved as, in recasting, I put only one quotation or
ref. to each card and, in the case of quotations, gave both the ver-
batim Spanish, Portuguese, Italian Mayan etc. and the translation. Not neces-
sary for the French, of course, as Dr. Frost reads it as readily as English
Old Spanish Italian and Portuguese, however, are difficult, even for one reading
the modern languages, so I thoughti, while waiting to work with him, I
could save him time by adding the translations.

Yes, the work has been “an effort...all this year,” but not
nearly so much so as last spring and summer when Miss Brown and I were
were
-2-
“working against time” in order to have things ready for Dr. Frost
by the end of the summer. Of course, as things turned out we could
have taken an occasional Sunday off, but there was no way to tell
that at the time and infinitely better for us to wait a long time
for Dr. Frost than to have him wait even a short time for us.

With all manner of good wishes for your own vacation
and hoping soon to be able to tell you when Dr. Frost wants me in
Baltimore.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
